name: Evil People Online Trivia | People | 10 Questions

questions.text: The Marquis De Sade gives us the term, sadism. He was also a writer. Which work is his?
questions.explanation:
Justine.

	The others are also 'naughty' books. De Sade spent a huge chunk of time in prison and in institutions.

questions.text: The term 'masochism' derives from Leopold Sacher-Masoch. What did he write?
questions.explanation:
Venus in Furs.

	The term was coined by Krafft-Ebing, the psychologist.

questions.text: Which of these gunmen from the Old West died quietly?
questions.explanation:
Wyatt Earp.

	Earp died quietly as an old man. Billy's life ended early when he was fatally shot by Pat Garrett. Jesse James was killed by Bob Ford. Hickock was shot while playing cards.

questions.text: The Broadway Show, 'Sweeney Todd,' was fictional, but there was a real Sweeney Todd. What was his profession?
questions.explanation:
Barber.

	The full name of the show was 'Sweeney Todd, the Demon Barber of Fleet Street.' He was hanged.

questions.text: Torquemada is the name most closely associated with the Spanish Inquisition. When did he live?
questions.explanation:
1400s.

	His life more or less spanned the century.

questions.text: Rasputin, 'the Mad Monk,' was a colorful character in Russian history. What happened to him?
questions.explanation:
He was murdered.

	He was poisoned, shot, and dumped in a river. I guess 'murder' is an accurate description.

questions.text: In describing evil acts that he describes as being caused by 'the spirit of the perverse,' this writer says: 'We perpetrate them because we feel we should not.'
questions.explanation:
Edgar Allan Poe.

	'The Imp of the Perverse,' by Poe. It anticipates unconscious motivation and Freudian psychology nicely, I think.

questions.text: Who was the commander of Andersonville Prison during the Civil War?
questions.explanation:
Henry Wirz.

	A monster--or just doing a tough job as best he could?

questions.text: Which of these characters was better known as 'Bluebeard'?
questions.explanation:
Gilles De Rais.

	Teach was the pirate, Blackbeard. Morgan was also a pirate. Selkirk was marooned, a la Robinson Crusoe.

questions.text: Rumor has it that Nero fiddled while Rome burned. Whatever happened to Nero?
questions.explanation:
Suicide.

	In fact, he was reluctant to kill himself by his own hand and ordered his secretary, Epaphroditus, to kill him.
